EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR ARG



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



At American Refining Group, Inc. (ARG), we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner. We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:



* Facility specific information and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulations

* Results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases

* An overview of or accidental release prevention programs

* A five year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP regulations

* An overview of our emergency response program

* Certification statement required by EPA

* Detailed information (data elements) about our risk management program



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



ARG produces petroleum base oils, naphthas, distillates, resins, extracts, gasoline, diesel fuel, fuel oils, and blended lubricant products. The oil refinery consists of a Crude Oil Tank Farm, Crude Distillation Unit, Unifiner/Platformer Unit, Isomerization Unit, ROSE (Deresining) Unit, MEK (Dewaxing) Unit, Extract Unit, Boiler House, and Bulk Loading (fuels, naphthas).  Of these processes/areas, the ROSE and MEK Units have each been identified as containing more than 10,000 pounds of a RMP regulated substance (propane) and are thus covered under EPA's RMP regulations.  The remaining processes/areas either do not contain flammable or toxic materials above threshold quantities, or contain mixtures of listed regulated flammable substances above the threshold quantity but are exempt based on Su

bpart F of the EPA's RMP rule. The ROSE and MEK processes contain the following RMP regulated flammable chemicals with the potential for causing off-site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:



ROSE Unit - propane is unloaded from trucks to E-1 storage vessel (72,000 lbs). Propane is used as a solvent in the ROSE process to extract resins from the cylinder stock charge.



MEK Unit - propane is unloaded from trucks to D-23/D-18 storage vessel (50,400 lbs). Propane is used for chilling the products charged to the MEK Unit for de-waxing operations. 



NOTE: These values are based on estimated quantities within the vessel. For the 2015 submission a "Worst Case" volume was used in which the vessel was assumed to be completely full. This conservative approach was used in that fluctuations in regards to unit shutdowns have increased volumes above the previously stated volumes thus by utilizing 100% inventory this would project for optimal worst case situations.



Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.



We use our off-site consequence analysis information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address potential scenarios.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key elements of successful provention programs including:



* Process Safety Information

* Process Hazard Analysis

* Operating Procedures

* Training

* Mechanical Integrity

* Management of Change

* Pre-Startup Safety Review

* Compliance Audits

* Incident Investigation

* Employee Participation

* Hot Work

* Contractors

* Emergency Planning & Response



These el

ements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our high standards for accident prevention.

We have had no accidental releases under EPA's RMP rule in the past five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



We maintain an Emergency Response Plan, which incorporates state and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. Our facility maintains volunteer emergency response teams for responding to emergency situations including a Fire Brigade, Hazardous Materials Response Team, Rope Rescue Team, and First Aid Medical Response Team.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. We are active participants in our Local Emergency Planning Commission (McKean County) and coordinate our plan with the community emergency response.  



RECENT AND PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



In 2010-2012 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) revalidation studies were conducted on all of ARG's PSM/RMP Covered Processes within the facility. These studies evaluated potentially new hazards and addressed any significant issues through recommended actions. These recommendations are being addressed appropriately to ensure continued safety throughout the facility. 



Significant improvements have been made in the plants infrastructure including fire protection equipment (deluge, fire trucks, etc...), replacement of aged equipment, and general increased maintenance of the fa

cility. The plants mechanical integrity has greatly improved its efficiency using a risk based inspection approach and a sophisticated tracking software for inspections. 



The company is adjusting its incident management system to focus on process related safety events using American Petroleum Insititue's (API) Recommended Practice (RP) 754 "Process Safety Performance Indicators for the Refining and Petrochemical Industries". This is with the intent to better understand the process related events that occur at the facility but also with the hopes to align with industry on a common reporting mechanism. 



American Refining Group is committed to quality environmental, health and safety programs. We strive to continuously improve our procedures and equipment.  We use audits, training, equipment inspections, recommendations from PHAs, and incident investigations to improve our environmental, health, and safety programs in order to better protect our employees and our community.
